data.text:
Jeff Mao

All right, good evening everybody. Welcome to our conversation this evening as a part of the Red Bull Music Academy NYC Festival. My name is Jeff Mao and our guest this evening is one of the great musical innovators of our times, you are undoubtedly familiar with his work as a recording artist, songwriter/composer, arranger, producer, and a mentor to others. And heâs, of course, the architect of the New Jack Swing sound.

Ladies and Gentlemen, please welcome Mr. Teddy Riley. [applause] Thank you so much for being here tonight.

Teddy Riley

Thanks for having me.

Jeff Mao

Youâre back here in New York, this is where it started for you.

Teddy Riley

This is home.

Jeff Mao

Is it always home, is it always feel like home.

Teddy Riley

Of course, all the time. Living in the projects will make you remember, and never forget, where you come from. And I never forget St. Nickâs Projects was the light of my life, and the start of my career.

Jeff Mao

Yeah.

Teddy Riley

Always remember my home.

Jeff Mao

Where would St. Nicholas Projects be, what part of the city would that be?

Teddy Riley

Harlem. The spot, you know, but I lived in every borough except Staten Island. So, [laughter] I just donât want to take the boat everywhere.

Jeff Mao

Thereâs still time, you could move to Staten Island, like right now.

Teddy Riley

I canât do it. I canât do it. Itâs too close to Governorâs Island. Anybody caught that? [laughter]

Jeff Mao

Well, Harlem is a great place to start actually, because I remember reading you describing New Jack Swing as a sound, and how Harlem was so intrinsic to that sound. I donât know if the definition of New Jack Swing has changed for you, but how would you define the New Jack Swing sound? What is New Jack Swing?

Teddy Riley

New Jack Swing, first of all was a name that was given to me, and I always have to give credit to Barry Michael Cooper who actually gave me the name because I didnât actually have a name for it. And it was just this music that was just transcending, and people were just catching on to it. Then you had record companies that didnât really give you a deal if you didnât have that sound.

So, we had to call it something right away because New Jack City was coming out. And I can remember sitting with Barry Michael Cooper, and he was interviewing me. He said, âWhat are you gonna call this?â And I said, âI donât know.â I never knew what my music was called, or what I would call it until he gave me that name. And he said, âNew Jack Swing. Iâm doin New Jack City, and you are the New Jack Swing. Youâre the new kid on the block thatâs swingin it.â So, I always thought if as the new kid on the block thatâs swinging it until I took it into another direction of making it... Itâs a technology of music, which is putting rap and singing together, and taking fusions of different music, and fusing them all together. Because I had this dream of seeing James Brown and Michael Jackson do a song together. I had this dream of seeing the Temptations and the Chi-Lites, or mixing groups together that I wanted to hear make music.

And when that didnât happen... It wasnât like a dream that didnât come true, because I made the dream come true anyway by taking their music and taking the essence. Not actually, literally taking their music, but the essence and what I was inspired by. I took it and just fused it together.

And I was always in church. So, I always had to have that church feel in my music. And thatâs what kept everyone on the dancefloor. I didnât really get it until I started seeing it. I wasnât old enough to go to the clubs to see it.

So, when I did Keith Sweat and thatâs when I got back into R&B, because I left it alone because the first R&B record that I did failed. And what I call a failure, cause it wasnât a failure to everybody, but what I call a failure is when I donât hear my record a lot on BLS, or WKTU, KISS, or the radio station that was happening back then, which was those three. I was like, âItâs not a hit.â So, I said Iâm leaving rap alone. Iâm just gonna work with rap artist. Iâm gonna leave R&B alone, Iâm sorry. Iâm gonna work with rap artist, and thatâs it. Iâm just gonna make beats for everybody and their mothers. Thatâs what I did.

I can remember in St. Nick Projects, all of my friends were just... âCause I lived on the first floor, and all of my friends would come to the window, and that how Iâd know I had a hit. So, the record that you just heard, âRapâs New Generation,â which was sampled by Mary J. Blige. That record I did in the actual Rooftop roller skating rink.

I donât know if anybody here are familiar. A lot of you are young in here. But, my uncle, Uncle Willie, I know you guys know about Willie Burgers on 145th Street, where you can get your turkey burgers, and your hamburgers, and the best... Well, thatâs my uncle. He owns Willie Burgers on 145th Street. He owned Celebrity Club, S&S, and 404 after-hours spot, and Rooftop roller skating rink, along with my partners. My partner Gusto. So, Gusto actually built me a studio, and when he built me a studio, I was in heaven. It was like, Iâm gonna be here. Iâm not going outside, and they see me there so much, they built a bedroom for me. Somewhere I can just lay my head, âcause I never want to leave the studio. Especially, I was in the projects and I didnât have a studio, it was like setting my stuff on my mom and my popâs old jukebox. We had a jukebox. One of the only families in the projects that had a jukebox where you could play records.

So, I use to set up my whole setup on the jukebox, and just make music, and Doug E. Fresh would come to my house and then Bobby would come to my house, and Keith Sweat came to my house. So, we made music, and Anna Hall slept on my couch. Every day we were making the Guy album, and all of these people came to my projects, and my A&Rs were all the kids, and all of my friends from the playground. If they came up to the window, I knew I had something. If they didnât come to the window, itâs like, âAh this ainât working.â And that's what told me... Especially my brother, my brother Markell from Wreckx-n-Effect. He was my number one A&R over all my music. And he would just tell me, âThatâs not gonna work. I donât think thatâs gonna work, because you gotta swing it more. You know how you did with Doug E.â He would give me references, and be really technical about it. I was just like, itâs a challenge for me âcause my own little brother is telling me he donât like something, and I would go and change it and it wind up working. Most of my hits came from my brother, or my friends from around the block. Theyâd come to the window and was like, âYo, thatâs hot. Thatâs hot,â then theyâd go back doing things, you know.

Jeff Mao

And so, itâs pretty good immediate feedback though. I wanted to ask you this, maybe a little bit more broadly and philosophically, is there a uptown Harlem, Bronx - whatever you want to call it - musical sensibility and style that helped inform what you created? You have this, swing, obviously with New Jack Swing, but there was a bounce to, I feel, a lot of music. Something about it, maybe not something you can put your finger on, or maybe itâd be hard for some people to describe technically or musically, but is there something that puts that sort of bounce into certain types of music from Harlem.

Teddy Riley

Yeah. It was, for me, church. And why I say church, because... The first church that I went to, which was Universal Temple, it was more like a mellow church. Youâd come in with your tambourine, and you just play your tambourine. I was the piano player for, I didnât have a drummer. So, I was like, man I wish I had a drummer. And the next thing you know, a family member of ours said, âYou should come to our church.â It was Universal Temple, actually across the street from the hospital I was born in, which is Harlem Hospital. Right around the corner, that was the church that I went to and the actual drummer of the church was Jazzy Jay from Afrika Bambaataa. And you have Jazzy Jay on the drums, you know youâre going to get that bounce. We used to try to play secular music in the church and we rocked secular music and we would play James Brown. [hums James Brown rhythm] Thatâs the bounce. I applied that to the music. Now, I used to go in the projects and they used to have the block parties or bring out the DJ equipment and everything. And I used to have a little Casio keyboard that had the beatbox and you play a key and itâs playing the beatbox and the chords and all of that. That bossa nova and that Casio type of sound. I used to take it in the park all the time, this is another reference of how I got the bounce. It had already beats in it and you hit this one key and the DJ was like [sings]... And what does that sound like? A bunch of records that are out later on after like that âI Want to Sex You Up.â

So that was the bounce. Thatâs how I started getting my flow and then hanging out with my friends who were DJs and I wasnât a DJ, I was the guy with a keyboard until I finally said you know what? Iâm going to learn how to DJ so I can do it all. Thatâs what got me into doing everything. My influences are Kid Creole, anybody familiar with Kid Creole? Kid Creole and then you had for my harmony and my vocal arrangements, I listened to Manhattan Transfer, I listened to Take Six, I listened to all of the groups and the singing groups that had that harmony, Temptations, which gave me a lot of influence to bounce my music with the singing. So I would get a bunch of records and start learning them all and learning how their sound really cultivated the people. Thatâs how I learned, just doing it myself and I didnât have a drum machine, I couldnât afford a drum machine so I used to take my microphone that my Mom had with her gospel singing group. I used to take her microphone, which was a Shure SM-57 and take a roll of toilet tissue and take the microphone and stick it in the hole of the toilet tissue and I would do something like this [beatboxes]. When I hit it, it was like my 808 but it didnât go long. [beatboxes] I was making all my beats that way, putting it on a Teac recorder, reel-to-reel. I would do all of my harmonies and then I had this little keyboard called the DX-100. This little keyboard called the DX-100, I would play everything with that until I could afford what I needed to make more music.

Jeff Mao

OK, letâs actually play something that you were an intrinsic part of. It wasnât any of those records you mentioned but you did mention the person behind this record as well.

(music: Doug E. Fresh & the Get Fresh Crew â âThe Showâ)

How about a little applause for that? [applause] Very famous record.

Teddy Riley

It is.

Jeff Mao

Very important record. How did this happen?

Teddy Riley

Well, I was introduced by a mutual friend, Lavaba Mallison, who introduced me to Doug E. because I didnât know that... I knew it was Doug E. because I used to go see Doug E. at the real Harlem World Club and he would perform...

Jeff Mao

Which was?

Teddy Riley

Which is on 116th street in Harlem, 116th street and Lenox Avenue. I would see Doug E. perform, I would see Larry Love, I would see Busy Bee, Lovebug Starski, Hollywood and Doug E. would always just rip it up because he was the first guy doing the human beatbox. I used to always be there, if Doug E.âs going to be there, Iâm going to be there but I never knew Doug E. I was just a fan and a hustler in the audience trying to figure out how Iâm going to get on that stage. I never got up there but front and center Iâd see him in high school and Iâm this fan in high school, thatâs Doug E.! Iâm not going to be all up on him like him, Iâm going to keep doing what I do and someday Iâm going to get to meet him. Then finally, three months in high school, I had gotten transferred to the high school and heâs been going there so heâs the guy thatâs the well-known guy in the school. I say you know what? Iâm going to get to meet him but I was very, very, shy to meet anybody. I had never met anybody in my school unless they came up to me.

But with Doug E., I actually got to meet him, and Lavaba brought him to my house. Itâs the best way to meet somebody because in high school they can son you or do something, yeah, itâs nice to meet you. I got to meet him, he came to my house, and we got right down to it and talked about the song and when he brought the actual song to me, it didnât have all of the things that you heard in the record until I told him, he said âWhat you would do with this?â He let me listen to it and put it on the cassette and he said, âWhat would you do to this?â I said, âFirst thing I would do is take out all of the commercials. Thereâs too many commercials, thereâs too many stops and drops.â

Jeff Mao

There were little skits embedded into the song?

Teddy Riley

Yes, more than this.

Jeff Mao

Yeah.

Teddy Riley

He had commercial after commercial maybe every eight bars or 16 bars and it was a stop. I said, âMan, if youâre going to keep that, you got to keep the people dancing. You need that element that is going to keep the people dancing. So I said all right, check this out.â I had a Oberheim DX drum machine and I opened it up and tuned down the drums, I tuned down the shaker and when I turned down they shaker, theyâre looking at me like this dudeâs about to break this drum machine or whatâs about to happen? So I open it up and I tuned down the shaker and I tuned down the tom tom so that I can get that low 808 sound. I said âWhat do you think of this? Play the cassette.â He played the cassette and I just said, âOKâ [beatboxes]. He said, âAll right, I like that. OK, what you going to do next?â I said, âAll right, we going to do this.â [beatboxes] That made the song, that made the whole song. He forgot about the drum sounds and all that stuff, he was like, âThatâs it, thatâs whatâs going to keep people going on the dancefloor so we can have a couple of these commercials and the drops and all of that stuff. That shakerâs going to keep going while we dropping it.â Thatâs how I was added to the song.

Jeff Mao

Was Inspector Gadget, was that part of it already or was that...

Teddy Riley

That too, I added that but that wasnât, no, no, no. The shaker was still it, the shaker was mainly it. The Inspector Gadget was something that we was intrigued about because itâs Inspector Gadget. After three oâclock, being in school, we wanted to see Inspector Gadget, didnât we? Thatâs how that came about and I knew it because that was a song that I learned teaching myself how to play. I said, âIâm going to learn this.â [sings Inspector Gadget theme]. Thatâs it too, but the shaker was the main thing. I always say, if youâre familiar with hooks and what really hooks you in a song, itâs really not the chorus. Itâs actually the pre-, the pre-chorus, that gets you wounded up and then you sing the hook, because youâve already been hooked. So, the [sings Inspector Gadget theme], that was the hook to get you into âAlright now, letâs go wild!â Yo, you just gonna do everything once that thing go [sings]. You just... You broke your neck to get on the dancefloor. And thatâs what Doug E. Fresh did to everyone. Heâs still doing it today. We do a lot of performances and that song still stands the test of time.

Jeff Mao

It does. Absolutely stands the test of time. I mean... And itâs just an unconventional song just in terms of what was coming out in hip-hop to that point. Just with the personality and the playfulness of it, and everything as well. I mean itâs funny because you mention the hook, the pre-hook, and I feel like a consistent theme with your music is these rhythmic hooks, I guess, whether it is the shakers or itâs, later, the string hits.

Teddy Riley

I tell you. The one thing that I put in my songs a lot is something that is going to give people either the beat instead of the lyrics, because you know a lot of people dance to the lyrics. Well, I always like to put... If you hear the song, âNew Jack Swing,â anyone familiar with that? All right, so in that song, thereâs a high sound that goes [squeaks]. So itâs like [deep breaths]. You know? Thatâs what keeps people going. Something that is going to keep you going. I just recently did the soundtrack for the [Harlem] Globetrotters, and âSweet Georgia Brown.â I remixed it and did something that kept people going... because if you look at the old Globetrotter round circle thing, and you got some people [whistles].

So, what I put in it was [squeaks] and a clap while swinging it and doing other stuff that other people wonât get unless they have the clap. So, when I did that, I had to do so many versions, and when I came back with the one that gives them the indication of, âThis is what everyoneâs gonna do when they hear the record,â is clap the same way as on the record. And everybody would be in sync. So thatâs my formula. I gotta have something in the end.

Thereâs another thing Iâll tell yâall that I put in my songs to make people emotional about it, whether theyâre happy, sad, or theyâre just in a different mode. But the music is gonna make you come into it. Everybody here have had a massage and when you go to the massage parlor, what do they play? They play music to make you calm. If you go online, there are tones online that will help you stop smoking or be hypnotized or get up and be happy, and that tone is in a lot of my songs. Iâm sorry, yâall. But itâs real. You can look online and look for tones to make you smile or make you sad.

And those tones you put in a song, and it gets to the person. It makes them feel emotional. You know, even if itâs an up-tempo, I can actually make you feel really... And I used to feel emotional about songs like... old songs like âLetâs Make a Babyâ and songs like Smokey Robinson songs will make me emotional. I get sad all of a sudden, even though itâs a happy song. And I donât know what it was but I had said to myself, I said, âI want to be able to do that for people.â And I can remember a woman telling me that âYour song, âThe Lord is Real,â made my family member change their minds about living. They wanted to live. Itâs like they wanted to die and they said when they heard that song, it changed their life and changed their minds. Now theyâre in church and theyâre doing great and well.â

They would come and say, âWhat do you do in your songs that make people do that?â First of all, itâs the subject. Itâs really the subjects. Itâs really about what weâre going through every day. And I like to talk about it. I like to write about it whether itâs lyrics. It doesnât have to be lyrics because my music is gonna tell you the story. Most of my writers who write to my songs automatically get the actual hook if I donât get it. They actually get the actual hook because it talks to them and thatâs what I want my music to do, is speak to people whether it has vocals or not.

Jeff Mao

What is that process like? Weâll go through some of the classics here. But you come in when youâre collaborating with a songwriter or an artist. Do you start with your rhythm? Does the process start before you get into the room together or does it only start when youâre in the room together and youâre starting to just work out a piece of music?

Teddy Riley

Most times I would start a song with my mouth. Iâm a big, big SoundCloud user, but you would never know because everything is private because I put all my ideas and Iâll hum it in my head and put the phone like this to my face and it gets, actually, a vibration of what Iâm doing because youâll hear the bottom and the vibration of what Iâm doing. And thatâs how I come up with my songs and Iâll take that because the software that I use which is called Studio One. I can actually take all my SoundCloud, because itâs integrated with SoundCloud, and put it in sequencer and then Iâll take the actual thing and do a beat detection on it so that I can have it in time. And once itâs in time, thatâs when I start creating.

And thatâs how my weird ideas happen, you know, because Iâll put it on a dictaphone, even before SoundCloud, even before computers and technology. I would have a little dictaphone and a few that Michael have given me. Heâs like, âMan, I know you do your ideas through dictaphone so I want to give you a real one.â Iâm like, âOK.â He gave me a DAT player from Japan and it was this small, as small as the DAT. And I would record anything. He would send us out to go record the lions and the tigers in his zoo and I would come back with just a bunch of stuff and make beats. And thatâs how I create my songs. It doesnât matter what comes first. It still starts from here. Everybody, it starts from here, with everyone.

So thatâs how I pretty much make my sounds... Now working with Michael. You canât go to the drum machine. You canât go to any of those things until we get past the piano. So when I first went to Michael and I started...

Jeff Mao

Hold on. Weâre gonna get there.

Teddy Riley

OK. You got it.

Jeff Mao

Donât wanna get there just yet. You got a couple more things to talk about before we get to Michael.

Teddy Riley

You got it. You got it. I would go on, yâall. I got stories for years.

Jeff Mao

No, just hold that thought. But before we get to that, we have to talk about a couple other things, including this.

(music: Keith Sweat â âI Want Herâ)

Teddy Riley

So while thatâs playing. These sounds were done on a Korg DDD-1. And my little DX-100. That bass sound, itâs called a Lately bass, and thatâs been used multi times with everyone. But I use that bass a whole lot. And the hits came from the drum machine because we didnât have a sampler. So I would sample and play all the hits with pads. And when I played that record for Keith, we had just finished playing, shooting a game of dice with everybody from around the block and we took their money and then we went inside. And he said, âMan, I want you to, if possible, make me some R&B music.â I said, âMan, Iâm done.â This was the time I was done with R&B. I just didnât want to do R&B because I was like, âMan, itâs gonna fail again. Iâm just gonna do these rap records.â He said, âMan, just take the chords.â A lot of people donât know how Keith Sweat and I, we met... Actually, we were rivals. He was in a band called Jamilah. I was in a band called Total Climax. And Johnny Kemp was in a band called Kinky Fox. And we used to travel the circuit, just in New York, never been on tour. Our tour was weâd go from the Cellar, to Jockâs Place, to the Rainyâs Lounge, to Tribecaâs and then we would switch. Kinky Fox, Johnny Kempâs band, would have the Cellar and theyâd be there for about four or five weeks. We would have Jockâs Place, weâd be there for four or five months until the Cellar would let us in for two weeks and then theyâll put Kinky Fox back in there because they were the house band. Keith Sweat, they would play the Rainyâs Lounge. They would play Blue Note. They would play a lot of different places. Atlantic City. We had a Big Apple contest at Grantâs Tomb. Keith Sweatâs band was against my band and I think Johnny Kempâs band was in it. Long story short, we won. And thatâs how Keith Sweat really looked at me as this kid from the block prodigy kid.

Jeff Mao

Very young at this point.

Teddy Riley

Yeah, I was actually 15. And heâs like, âMan, if you could take them church chords that you do and just put it with them rap beats that you do, you know, this could be great.â I said, âGive me a day.â He gave me just a day and, luckily, Iâm eager about music. I canât stop doing it. Itâs my life, itâs in my bloodstream. So I went in that house and I said... I wasnât really... I donât know how to take a challenge so itâs like Iâmma do it anyway, doesnât matter. I came up with this beat, and when I came up with this beat, I didnât know what I was doing. I just knew that it will be very interesting to people when I see them dance to it. And it would be very, to me, exciting seeing them really be like gettinâ down, just doing what you want.

Thatâs what New Jack Swing did to people. You didnât have a certain dance you wanted to do. You just did what came to your mind because of the rhythm of the music. You was just doinâ anything. The freak, or whatever it was. And thatâs what it did when we made it. I had to get somebody and I can remember my sister coming out of the room and sheâs like, âAhhhh thatâsâ¦!!!â And sheâs like doing the foot, you know, keep the foot up there. Iâm like, âWhat are you doing?â Sheâs like, âThatâs how they gonna dance on the record. You wanted me to show you that.â And my brother was just too young to know. He just wanted to go outside and blow up M80s and all that stuff. And blew his finger in half. And Iâm still making these beats and he come inside, no response at all. That was a time when he was just... I dunno what my brother was doing...

Jeff Mao

He lost his inner child that day.

Teddy Riley

He was like whatever my brotherâs doin, Iâm going out, blowing some firecrackers and whatever. And my sister, my Uncle Butchie. Everybody have a uncle that is just always in your business. My uncle was the guy that always came in and just try and sing or just get in the middle of your song. And youâre like, âUncle Butch, come on man. Lemme just... I gotta do this man. I gotta finish. Keith Sweatâll be here tomorrow.â Heâs like, âWhoâs Keith? Whoâs Keith? I know that music sound good. You just keep playinâ. I want to sing something to it.â

So those are the things that I got but that was the beauty of making music, âcause you always had somebody to let you know with some sort of sign. And thatâs the sign that I got. When I finally played it for him, âYo, baby, thatâs hot. Yo, we can bring that down to the studio whatchu got for it?â I said, âAlright, Iâmma click on the vocals. Donât laugh at my vocals, all right?â âGo ahead, baby.â [beatboxes] I said, âWhatchu think?â He said, âAll right, play the vocals.â âI wanna... I wanna...â And he said, âWhatâs it sayin?â Because it sounds like Iâm saying âHigh wanna.â âCause thatâs the way that I did the vocals and I said high wanna but itâs I wanna. And heâs like, âYo. What should I sing?â I said, âI donât know but you shouldnât sing it high.â Because Keith Sweat was a falsetto singer in his songs. He did âReasonsâ and âAlways and Forever.â He would do all of those high parts.

Jeff Mao

Keith Sweat was a falsetto singer? Really?

Teddy Riley
